newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Clerides says Cyprus accord would halt missile plan.
newsitem.headline: Clerides says Cyprus accord would halt missile plan.

text.p: A plan to install Russian-made S-300 air defence missiles in Cyprus next year would be scrapped if an agreement was reached on the Cyprus problem, President Glafcos Clerides said on Tuesday.

In an interview with Reuters, he said five days of U.N.-sponsored talks beginning on Wednesday with Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash will provide an opportunity for "an exchange of views on some of the main issues, perhaps agree on an agenda for the next talks, and measure how flexible the other side is.

"More than likely there would be another session some time in August," he said, but noted a presidential election campaign in the Greek Cypriot-administered south of the island would make further negotiations difficult later on.
Clerides, 78, said he was still considering running for re-election in February 1998 and will make a decision after September.
Cyprus has been virtually partitioned since troops from Turkey took over the north of the island in 1974 in reaction to a coup in Nicosia backed by the junta then ruling Greece.

Adding urgency to the latest effort to end the division of the island are plans by the Nicosia government to install S-300 missiles some time in 1998. Turkey, which is only 40 miles (65 km) from Cyprus and would lose air superiority over the island, has vowed to prevent this.

Asked whether there were any circumstances that would result in scrapping the deployment of missiles, he replied, "Yes. If we reach an agreement on the solution of the Cyprus problem, the agreement would also contain a provision for demilitarization of the island. And therefore ... there would be no S-300s, or any missiles or any armies."

Questioned about Denktash's insistence on recognition of the Turkish Cypriot community's sovereign equality with that of the Greek Cypriots, he said, "I don't think that the sovereignty of a nation springs from the number of communities that there are in that country."

Clerides, whose Greek Cypriot-led administration is recognised internationally as the legitimate government of the whole of Cyprus, said, "I see it as the U.N. sees it, as the whole world sees it. There is one sovereign state and that is the Republic of Cyprus."

Referring to repeated efforts by the United Nations to establish a bi-zonal, bi-communal federation, he said, "What we are about to do is to change the constitution ... from that of a unitary state to a federal state."
The 1963 breakup of a government in which both communities had been represented made no difference. "If a government collapses, the sovereignty of a country does not collapse," he said.
